text:
Fellow strategists, what kind of research do you do to understand your clients' markets better?

Do you spend a specific amount of time on that per week? Per month? Is it built into your contracts?

And are there any courses you've taken or are taking that you'd recommend?

Just trying to figure out what a reasonable amount of background work looks like on top of writing content for clients.

text:
Are we assuming that the clients know/understand their audience? Or are you doing all that work from scratch?

If they know, I like to build out a dossier and interview the social media team and sales - most of the time they can give some great insight into issues that they might not have been forthright about with their own marketing teams.

elements.text:
Are we assuming that the clients know/understand their audience? Or are you doing all that work from scratch?

If they know, I like to build out a dossier and interview the social media team and sales - most of the time they can give some great insight into issues that they might not have been forthright about with their own marketing teams.

text:
I have a similarly manual process to <@U02EXH0TYBT>. We have all of our blogs as AirTable cards.

We've had to change URLs a few times, so I just export traffic over some time period from Analytics (e.g. 2020 traffic) and match them to AirTable entries with a VLOOKUP in Excel.

So even though we change the URLs, I have at least some historical data. The trick is you have to do it in advance :slightly_smiling_face:

You could presumably pull all your 301 redirects and line them up with the "destination" post somehow...

You could presumably pull all your 301 redirects and line them up with the "destination" post somehow...

text:
Hey there! We typically do this only for case studies that have some solid numbers.

Not sure it's worth doing a whole campaign around if:
• you don't have quantifiable results to talk about
• the customer's brand is not big enough
That said, we've seen best results if we go at it industry-wise. For example, I'd pick a different case study for targeting BFSI segment and a different one for eCommerce, etc.

We've seen better results with display campaigns than InMails. However, we saw good results when we shared the case study with prospect(s) our team was already connected with on LinkedIn. Here's what we did:

1. Converted the case study into a mobile-friendly, short one-pager, and shared it with relevant prospects on LinkedIn. Saw good results - both in terms of warming up cold deals and generating interest from new prospects.
2. InMails haven't worked well for us, but then again, it could be because our TA was too small.
That's all I have - hope this helps!

elements.text:
Hey there! We typically do this only for case studies that have some solid numbers.

Not sure it's worth doing a whole campaign around if:
you don't have quantifiable results to talk about
the customer's brand is not big enough

That said, we've seen best results if we go at it industry-wise. For example, I'd pick a different case study for targeting BFSI segment and a different one for eCommerce, etc.

We've seen better results with display campaigns than InMails. However, we saw good results when we shared the case study with prospect(s) our team was already connected with on LinkedIn. Here's what we did:

Converted the case study into a mobile-friendly, short one-pager, and shared it with relevant prospects on LinkedIn. Saw good results - both in terms of warming up cold deals and generating interest from new prospects.
InMails haven't worked well for us, but then again, it could be because our TA was too small.
That's all I have - hope this helps!

text:
<@U02EARBFRMK> I'm working with smaller brands/those just starting to build their communities, so they don't have a ton of knowledge in this area. Some have sales data or social media feedback and product reviews.

So it's not "from scratch," but it's also not deep knowledge.

text:
Love these kinds of businesses! My husband is in the HVAC business, so the whole service-business industry and related content intrigues me.

I pulled up some keyword analytics info from a HVAC CRM tool that we looked at a few years ago.

They are getting traffic from articles about memes! Like *'24 best electrician jokes and memes'.* They also rank for keywords like *how to find plumbing jobs, etc.,*

Looks like calculators for estimating is a big thing also. Maybe create a Job estimator similar to your Pricing calculator.

Who's your target audience? The Owner, the office manager, dispatcher...?

elements.text:
